snippet: In 2011, New York City officers frisked nearly 16,000 women; stops of women by male officers, some say, often involve additional embarrassment and sexual intimidation.
abstract: Law enforcement data shows that in 2001, New York City officers frisked nearly 16,000 women; laws governing street stops are blind to gender, but critics say stops of women by male officers often involve additional embarrassment and sexual intimidation.

byline.contributor: Ray Rivera and Tom Torok contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: In 2011, New York City officers frisked nearly 16,000 women; stops of women by male officers, some say, often involve additional embarrassment and sexual intimidation.

headline.seo: In Police Pat-Downs, Many Women See Sexual Overtones
headline.main: For Women in Street Stops, Deeper Humiliation
headline.print_headline: For Women in Street Stops, Deeper Humiliation
